page.text: Savannah, GA | Charleston, SC | Columbia, SC | Myrtle Beach, SC | Brunswick, GA
General Description of Proposed PUD and Definitions............................................................... 1
The proposed Harmony Planned Unit Development (Harmony PUD) is located in
the City of Charleston (City). The property is currently zoned SR–1. D.R. Horton is
proposing to rezone the property as a P l a n n e d Unit Development (PUD)
under Article 2 – Land Use Regulations, Part 7 Planned Unit Development District
of the City’s Code of Ordinances. The proposed Harmony PUD will consist of
residential dwellings, commercial development, recreational amenities, and
open space and development standards appropriate for the real estate market.
The property is located in the West Ashley region of Charleston adjacent to the
Glenn McConnell Parkway with access from Goodwill Way via Shelby Ray
Court. The property is bounded on the north by the Seaboard Coast Line
Railroad Right–of–way, to the east by the existing Canterbury Woods
residential subdivision, on the south by the marshes of Church Creek and the
west by Glenn McConnell Parkway. The property has three existing access points.
The Shelby Ray Court access links the property to Glenn McConnell Parkway at
Goodwill Way (non–signalized) and at Wildcat Blvd. (signalized). The property also
has linkage to the existing Canterbury Woods subdivision at Pinehurst Avenue and
Wicklowe Drive. The Properties included in this PUD submittal are graphically
articulated on a boundary plat of the property prepared by RLA Associates and
The Boundary Plat of the property includes adjacent p r o p e r t y ownership. The
total property is approximately 166 acres consisting of approximately 91 acres
of uplands, and approximately 75 acres of wooded wetlands and marsh.
A Site Analysis is included as Exhibit B and includes the properties wetlands,
topography, existing easements, general tree cover, natural features, adjacent
schools, adjacent parks and view corridors. Significant civic uses adjacent to
the property include West Ashley High School to the west, a Montessori
School within the Canterbury Woods subdivision to the east and the West
Ashley Park to the south. The Wetlands on the property have been staked in
the field and submitted to United States Army Corps of Engineers for approval.
This wetlands indicated on the map are for preliminary planning, a final wetlands
verification s h a l l b e approved by the United States Army Corps of Engineers
(Corps) prior to submittal to the City for development of future phases of the
property. Topography for the property is typical of the area and ranges from a high
of 16 and a low of 6 at the marsh edge.
Exhibit C is an aerial photograph of the property and illustrates the existing tree
The Harmony PUD constitutes an amendment to the current City of Charleston
Ordinances. The intent of the Harmony PUD is to create a mixed use development
within the City complete with a variety of housing options to meet current
market demands coupled with neighborhood parks, a n e i g h b o r h o o d t r a i l
s yst e m , a recreational amenity area, and neighborhood commercial uses. The
Conceptual Master Plan for the Harmony PUD (Master Plan) is included as Exhibit
D. The Master Plan envisions two land use Tracts including T h e Commercial
Tract and The Residential Tract. One–family attached dwellings consisting of
Townhouses shall be allowed within the Residential tract, as indicated on
Neighborhood recreational opportunities will be achieved by the Harmony PUD’s
commitment to usable open space. An Open Space summary is included on
the Conceptual Master Plan. (Exhibit D) The residential development will include
sidewalks down both sides of the streets which will in turn be linked to a
neighborhood trail system. The neighborhood trail system will link a series of
pocket parks and the neighborhood amenity center to residential development.
The system of trails, sidewalks and pocket parks within the Harmony PUD create
the potential to link the property to the surrounding schools and parks reducing
Proposed streets within The Harmony PUD have been established based on natural
features of the site which create logical edges. The neighborhood entry street
running from the Shelby Ray Court connection to the Residential Tracts shall be an
unloaded road with a rural street section and an 8 foot wide bike trail down one
side. Residential streets will include sidewalks down both sides. Refer to Exhibit F for
A traffic study has been completed for the Harmony PUD for the two connections
to Glenn McConnell Parkway, Goodwill Way (non–signalized) and at Wildcat Blvd.
(signalized), and is included as Exhibit E. The traffic study indicates that to alleviate
delays at the W. Wildcat Blvd./Mary Adler Avenue and Glenn McConnell Parkway
a third land on the Mary Adler Avenue approach with 150 feet of storage would
be recommended. While the development will also connect to Highway 61
through the Canterbury Woods subdivision, it is anticipated that a larger number
of trips will be diverted from Canterbury Woods through the proposed
development to Glenn McConnell Parkway than from the proposed development
through Canterbury Woods to Highway 61. As such, a decrease in total trips would
be anticipated at the existing affected Highway 61 intersections. An updated
traffic study including the impacts to and affects from the Highway 61 intersection
shall be provided to the City for approval prior to development.
Thomas and Hutton have completed a preliminary stormwater study included
herein as Exhibit F. Per that study stormwater runoff from the development
generally discharges through a network of onsite wetlands to southern property
line and Church Creek, and ultimately to the Ashley River. This discharge pattern
will be maintained by the developed site with peak flow rate attenuation and post-
development water quality treatment provided to meet applicable local and
Master Plan, Zoning Text and Development Schedule
The PUD Master Plan and zoning text outline the general scope of
development including number of dwellings, development standards, open
The provisions of the Master Plan and Zoning Text, Exhibits, and Appendices
shall apply to development of the Harmony PUD. In the event of a conflict, the
hierarchy of documents that control development shall be the Harmony PUD
followed by the City of Charleston Zoning ordinance.
Section II of this PUD zoning text identifies allowed land uses and densities for
t h e Residential and Commercial Tracts.
In the absence of a term definition in Harmony PUD, the definitions included in
the City of Charleston Code of Ordinances shall apply.
A subordinate building on the same lot as the principal building(s) or use.
Accessory buildings may include, but not be limited to, pool houses,
additional living space, storage sheds, and garages. Accessory buildings
within the Residential Tract shall not include kitchens, and shall not be used
A use of land or of a building or portion thereof customarily incidental and
subordinate to the principal use of the land or building and located on the
same lot with the principal use.
This designation allows for the recreational amenities to serve the Harmony
PUD. Land uses may consist of private indoor and outdoor lighted and
unlighted recreation facilities for active and passive sports. Permitted uses
Swimming pools, pool bath houses and gazebos/pavilions.
Note: Outdoor recreational facilities listed in (a.) above shall be
A separate detached building designed for and occupied exclusively as a
residence by one family. One–family detached dwelling within the
Harmony PUD shall comply with the site and land development regulation
of the SR–6 zoning district of the City of Charleston Code of Ordinances or
A building designed for and occupied exclusively as a residence by one
family, being attached by means of a common dividing structural side wall
or walls to one or more buildings likewise designed for and occupied as a
residence for one family. A single housing unit occupies each structure from
ground to roof and independent access is available for each unit from the
outside. Such attached one–family dwellings are commonly referred to as
"town," "patio," or "row" houses. One–family attached dwelling within the
Harmony PUD shall comply with the development regulations established
Limited Business is intended to provide for a limited variety of commercial
uses and services associated with neighborhood retail, financial, and office
activities which are compatible with residential areas. The hours of
operation for the most permitted commercial uses are shall be restricted to
between 7 a.m. and 11 p.m. Gasoline service stations are permitted as a
conditional use. Prohibited uses include, but are not limited to, bars, liquor
stores, car washes as a principal use, bowling alleys, billiard parlors, dance
halls, restaurants with drive–thru service windows, and automobile sales.
Limited Business within the Harmony PUD shall comply with the site and land
development regulation of the LB zoning district of the City of Charleston
The Maintenance Areas will contain the facilities, tools, and equipment
to maintain common property. These facilities may be
congregated on a central site or located in separate convenient sites for
different services such as general community maintenance, recreation
area maintenance, or individual property regime maintenance. At a
minimum, maintenance areas shall be screened by plants and a solid
fence or wall, at least the height of the item being screened, but not more
than eight feet tall. Plants shall be a minimum of 36” in height, evergreen,
and spaced 4’ on center at the time of planting. Screening shall be
provided around all sides, excluding access areas. Access gates to these
areas shall be solid and, to the extent practical, not be oriented to a public
street. Screening material and design shall be approved by the HOA.
Storage of equipment, vehicles, parts, boats, recreational vehicles
Storage of maintenance equipment and bulk maintenance
This designation allows for the model homes associated with the primary
sale of residential lots and homes.
Any parcel or area of land or water essentially unimproved and set aside,
dedicated, designated, or reserved for public or private use or enjoyment,
or for the use and enjoyment of owners and occupants of land adjoining
or neighboring such open space. Open space shall not include streets,
drives, off–street parking and loading areas, area so located or of such size
or shape to have no substantial aesthetic or recreational value and any
Total open space for the Harmony PUD shall be calculated for the
boundary of the Property and not on a site specific basis for each
Tract, individual development phase or project. General open space shall
Open space areas of high ground developed to provide active
recreational uses. Usable open space may consist but is not limited to:
This designation allows for the office/administrative facilities associated
with the primary sale of residential lots and homes. The facility(ies) may
be permanent in nature or a temporary mobile building that may relocate
from time to time during the period of development to meet the needs
Setbacks and buffers shall meet the minimum requirement established
herein; provided, however, that any required wetlands buffers shall apply
according to law throughout the Property. Wetland buffers shall be a
minimum of 35’ adjacent to the OCRM critical line and an average of 25’
but not less than 15’ adjacent to all other wetland areas unless otherwise
specified in a wetlands permit approved by the Army Corps of Engineers.
Wetland buffers shall allow selective clearing and tree pruning as allowed
by the South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control
and the City’s Tree Protection Ordinance.
Landscape buffer requirements specified in Article 3 – Site Regulations,
Part 8 Landscape Buffer Requirements of the City of Charleston Code of
Ordinances shall apply along the upland perimeter property lines and
upland perimeter of the OCRM critical line.
Perimeter setbacks and buffers are indicated on the Conceptual Master
Allowed uses within perimeter setback and buffer zones shall include:
Vegetative landscape development (no new impervious areas)
Signage for the Harmony PUD shall comply with Article 4 - Sign Regulations
of the City of Charleston Code of Ordinances.
The Harmony PUD has been divided into two (2) planning Tracts as indicated on
the Master Plan included as Exhibit D. The Tracts include:
An overall density cap for the Harmony PUD has been established at 260
dwelling units and 16,000 square feet of neighborhood commercial development
(conditioned space). Refer to Table #1, Harmony PUD Acreage Summary and
Density Standards for a breakdown of proposed uses.
Table #1 Harmony PUD Acreage Summary and Density Standards
One–family attached housing may be converted to one–family detached
housing provided the maximum residential density shall not exceed 260
Allowed Land Uses and Development Standards
The purpose of this portion of the Harmony PUD document is to state which land
uses shall be allowed within individual Tracts, however, allowing these land
uses and densities does not obligate the Property Owner or his successors to
develop the uses, densities or facilities stated herein. The following land uses as
designated for each individual Tract shall be permitted in the Harmony PUD. The
development standards for each use are outlined in Table #2, Harmony PUD
Development Standards in Section III of this zoning text.
The following uses as defined herein:
The following uses as defined herein:
The Following development criteria shall apply to the Northern Tract, The Southern Tract
Maximum height shall be the shorter of the two listed values
Setbacks are measured to the face of proposed structures.
Accessory structures are permitted in the rear and side yards only with
indicated minimum setbacks from the front and side property lines.
Corner lots shall comply with development criteria listed in this chart and be
considered to have one front, two sides and a rear.
All amenities and facilities are to be ADA compliant.
Off-street parking shall be provided at a minimum of 2 spaces per unit with a
combination of driveway and garage spaces. Driveway spaces shall be provide a
minimum of 20 feet between the back of sidewalk and face of garage or adjacent
Open Space for the Harmony PUD shall be a minimum of twenty (20) percent of the gross
acreage; twenty–five (25) percent of the required open space shall be developed and
Pocket parks (adjacent to trails and sidewalks)
A preliminary Stormwater Analysis for the Harmony PUD is included herein as Exhibit E. The
Property Owner or his successors will prepare a storm water management plan for
each phase of the Harmony project as it is submitted for development permit. The
stormwater management plan shall be in accordance with the current stormwater
management standards of the City. The plan will address site hydrological
characteristics, predevelopment conditions, post development runoff, and storm water
management facilities for flood control and treatment. The storm water management
plan will consider future construction, and it will detail the ability of the designed system
to treat runoff and control release rates during storm events as required.
Additionally, wetlands verification by the Army Corps of Engineers and applicable fill
permits shall be provided prior to approval of the above referenced plan(s).
The Wetlands on the property have been staked in the field by an environmental
consultant and surveyed. The wetland survey included in this PUD has been submitted to
United States Army Corps of Engineers for wetland delineation approval. This wetlands
indicated on the map are for preliminary planning, a final wetlands verification shall be
approved by the United States Army Corps of Engineers (Corps) prior to submittal to the
City for development of future phases of the property.
The property is located in the West Ashley region of Charleston adjacent to the Glenn
McConnell Parkway with access from Goodwill Way via Shelby Ray Court. The property
has three existing access points. The Shelby Ray Court access links the property to Glenn
McConnell Parkway at Goodwill Way (Non–signalized) and at Wildcat Blvd. (signalized).
The property also has linkage to the existing Canterbury Woods subdivision at Pinehurst
Avenue and Wicklowe Drive. The Harmony PUD shall maintain vehicular linkage at each
existing access point to promote connectivity of street systems in the area.
Street construction shall comply with the design standard of the City of Charleston Code
of Ordinances. Street sections are included as Exhibit F.
Thomas & Hutton has completed a traffic study included herein as Exhibit G. The Harmony
PUD shall comply with the suggested improvement recommended by the study.

text.b: WATER AND SEWER SERVICE/UTILITY SERVICES/STREET LIGHTS/ADDITIONAL PUBLIC SERVICES

page.text: Water and Sewer service shall be provided to development within the Property.
Septic tanks shall not be allowed. Intent to serve letters from Charleston Water System
Developers within the Property shall provide electrical and gas utility services. An
I nt en t t o serve letter from SCE&G is included in Exhibit H.
Developers within the property shall coordinate the placement of proposed street
lights with the street tree planting required in, IX. T r e e P r o t e c t i o n a n d L a n d s c a p e
R e q u i r e m e n t s below to avoid conflict between the two streetscape elements.
Additional intent to serve letters from other local public service providers is included in
Tree Protection for the Harmony PUD shall comply with Article 3 - Site regulations,
Part 6 – Tree Protection Requirements of the City of Charleston Code of
The Harmony PUD shall comply with the landscape and buffer requirements
included in Article 3 – Site Regulations, Part 8 - Landscape and Buffer Requirements
of the city of Charleston Code of Ordinance.
Streets within The Harmony PUD shall comply with Article 8 – Subdivision, Property Line
Adjustment or Abandonment, Part 3 – Subdivision Design Standards, Sec. 54-821. Street
design standards with the exception of the neighborhood entry street running from the
Shelby Ray Court connection through the commercial tract to the residential tracts which
shall be an unloaded road with a rural street section and 8 foot wide bike trail along one
side. See Exhibit E for typical street sections including that for the rural entrance street.
Sight distance visibility at all exits and/or intersections will be maintained in accordance
with the SCDOT Access and Roadside Management Standards (ARMS) Manual
Signage for the Harmony PUD shall comply with Article 4 - Sign regulations of the City of
The streets within the Harmony PUD shall include street lights. Street lights shall be
selected from the decorative fixtures offered by SCE&G. Light pole spacing shall be
based on the photometric design standards recommended by SCE&G. Final light
pole locations shall be coordinated with the street tree plantings to avoid conflict.
Prior to the sale of any property, a Master Property Owners Association (MPOA) shall be
established. Membership in the MPOA will be mandatory for any property owner. There
may be individual Property Owner Associations (POA’s) established for each parcel or
group of parcels, as the case may be, which will incorporate its own common
areas and be managed by each POA and governed by the MPOA. The MPOA may
be funded by dues to be established in its recorded restrictive covenants. The MPOA’s
responsibility will be to manage the affairs of the MPOA including the enforcement
of the restrictive covenants and the maintenance of common areas. Common areas
will include passive park space, landscape areas and stormwater detention facilities.

text.b: ONE FAMILY ATTACHED HOUSING MAY BE CONVERTED TO ONE-FAMILY DETACHED HOUSING PROVIDED THE
MAXIMUM DENSITY FOR THE HARMONY PUD DOES NOT EXCEED 260 DU’S.

Accessory structures are permitted in the rear and side yards only with indicated minimum setbacks from the side and rear property lines.
Corner lots shall comply with development criteria listed in this chart and be considered to have one front, two sides and a rear.

page.text: A new development is planned on the Harmony tract north of Glenn McConnell Parkway
(Figure 1). It is currently envisioned to include approximately 182 single family detached homes
and 54 attached residential units. The main access to the development is planned on Shelby
Ray Court, which leads to Glenn McConnell Parkway. It is assumed that the development will
be built out over the next 3 years.
This study will evaluate the traffic impacts of the currently proposed master plan. The morning
and afternoon peak hour traffic conditions will be evaluated at surrounding intersections, with
and without the proposed development. The following intersections will be included in the
Glenn McConnell Parkway and Mary Ader Ave / Wildcat Blvd
Glenn McConnell Parkway and Goodwill Way / William Murray Blvd
Glenn McConnell Parkway is a 4-lane divided facility with a 55 mph speed limit.
At the Mary Ader Ave / Wildcat Blvd intersection, Glenn McConnell Parkway has two lanes in
each direction. Westbound, there is a right turn lane for vehicles entering Mary Ader Ave and
dual left turn lanes for vehicles entering Wildcat Blvd. Eastbound, there is a left turn lane for
vehicles entering Mary Ader Ave and a right turn lane for vehicles entering Wildcat Blvd. The
southbound approach (Mary Ader Ave) provides a left and a combination through/right turn
lane. The northbound approach (Wildcat Blvd) provides a left, a combination through/right/left
lane, and a right turn lane. The intersection is signalized; the side streets operate under split-
At the Goodwill Way / William Murray Blvd intersection, Glenn McConnell Parkway has two lanes
in each direction. There are right and left turn bays on Glenn McConnell Parkway approaching
the intersection in each direction. The William Murray Blvd leg of the intersection is channelized
to allow only right-in, right-out movements. All movements all permitted to and from Goodwill
Way (except the through movement to William Murray Blvd).
Traffic operations at intersections are typically evaluated in terms of “Level of Service” or LOS.
The LOS is a measurement of delay incurred at an intersection or for a particular movement.
LOS is defined by the Transportation Research Board’s Highway Capacity Manual (HCM) from
which LOS A represents free flow conditions with minimal delays; LOS F represents congested
conditions. Generally, a LOS D or better is considered acceptable.
Table 1 shows the HCM criteria for both signalized and unsignalized intersections.
Peak hour traffic counts were taken at the study intersection in August 2014. Morning counts ran
from 6AM to 9AM in order to capture the traffic associated with West Ashley High School. The
peak hours during the morning and afternoon are shown in Figure 2; details of the count data
Capacity analyses were completed based on the 2014 counts. Signal timings were requested
but have not yet been provided by the City; analyses are based on an optimal cycle length
determined using Synchro software. Results are shown in Table 2.
Based on the current volumes, delays at the Wildcat/ Mary Ader intersection are very long in the
morning peak hour. The intersection operates with less delay in the afternoon peak hour, as
school traffic has likely dissipated by the afternoon commuter periods.
The Goodwill Way / William Murray intersection operates with relatively little delay, as the turning
SCDOT count station 684 is located on Glenn McConnell Parkway between Bees Ferry Road and
Magwood Drive. Historical volumes, obtained from SCDOT count station data, are shown in
Table 3. SCDOT count station data is included in the appendix.
Based on the SCDOT data, traffic on the surrounding roadways has remained relatively constant
There are several new developments in various stages of planning, design or construction along
Bees Ferry Road. In the immediate vicinity of the proposed project, however, there are no new
developments anticipated in the next few years.
As a general assumption, the 2014 peak hour volumes on Glenn McConnell Parkway are raised
by 2% annually to account for background growth of the area. The 2017 “No-build” volumes are
Trips generated by the proposed development are estimated using the standard rates and
equations from the Institute of Transportation Engineers, Trip Generation, 9
The assumed directional distribution of the site traffic is based on current travel patterns and the
recent counts at the study intersections. The AM and PM peak hours showed slightly different
distributions, which are reflected in the assumptions below. General distribution patterns are
shown in Figure 4 and are assumed as follows:
The site-generated trips are assigned to the study intersections based on the trip distribution
assumptions. Site generated trips are shown in Figure 5.
The site generated volumes (Figure 5) are added to the no-build volumes (Figure 3) to determine
the morning and afternoon design volumes (Figure 6). The future volumes are used to calculate
the intersection Levels of Service with and without the proposed development.
As mentioned, volumes in the morning peak hour are extremely high at the Mary Ader / Wildcat
intersection. Additional traffic generated by the Harmony development will add to the volumes
and delays at the intersection. As a means of alleviating these additional delays, a third lane on
the Mary Ader approach could be constructed.
The third lane on the Mary Ader Ave approach could be constructed as a right turn lane only.
This could allow the current through/right lane to be reconfigured as a through/left turn lane.
Since the intersection operates under split phases, the southbound approach could operate
with two lanes turning left (as the northbound Wildcat Blvd approach currently does).
For consistency, all analyses assume an optimized cycle length. The “No-Build” and “Build Out”
conditions assume the current intersection configuration. The “Build Out with improvement”
conditions assume that an additional lane is added to the Mary Ader Ave approach. Results of
the capacity analyses are shown in the Table 6.
With the additional turn lane on the Mary Ader Ave approach, operational levels at the
intersection (with the Harmony development) will remain roughly the same as the no-build

improvements, additional traffic generated by the Harmony development will add to the delays
at the intersection. As a means of alleviating these additional delays, the following is
Construct a third lane on the Mary Ader Ave approach with 150 feet of storage
